results.title: Bronzed Aussie gods
results.creator_credit: Michael Murray, Nick Bleszinski and Light Source Films
results.brief_description: The Beach is part of Australia’s cultural landscape, the surf lifesavers the guardians of this beautiful, but potentially dangerous terrain. Saving lives is not all these lifesavers do, at the end of every summer the Australian National Surf Lifesaving Titles (affectionately referred to as the “Aussies” by lifesaving aficionados) are held in April on the Gold Coast. Featuring over 6,000 competitors, this prestigious event is the second largest sporting event in number of athletes only to the Olympics. ‘Bronzed Aussie Gods’ follows three groups of men and women in training as lifesavers, performing real life rescues, enjoying their work, and vying for title glory. Interspersed with their plight is a trip down memory lane courtesy of archival footage capturing the changing customs and costumes that celebrate Australia’s unique relationship with the beach. This results in a film which celebrates Australian beach culture and maps the evolution of a strong aspect of Australian identity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Murray, Nick Bleszinski and Light Source Films

results.title: Bronze
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film presents the conception and execution of a work of art - a monumental bronze work by Montreal sculptor Charles Daudelin, now standing outside the National Arts Centre in Ottawa. Shows the shaping of the model in its styrofoam stage with knife, saw and blowtorch. The film is without words, but with music to evoke the mood. Credits: Photography by Thomas Vamos and Michel Thomas-d’Hoste; edited by Yves Leduc; music by Maurice Blackburn and sound by Claude Delorme.

results.title: Bronski Beat: the first chapter
results.brief_description: Openly gay, the Bronskis became cover darlings of the British music press in 1984 after the U.K. success of their first two singles, “Why” and “Smalltown Boy” (the latter producing one of the best music videos of all time). A synth-pop trio from London, everything that made Bronski Beat interesting, and at times compelling, came primarily from the larynx of Glasgow-born vocalist Jimmy Somerville. This tape is comprised of mainly music videos.

results.title: Broken harvest
results.creator_credit: Kate O'Callaghan, Maurice O'Callaghan, Jerry O'Callaghan and Destiny Films
results.brief_description: The death of his mother triggers a flashback for Jimmy O’Leary and life in Northern Ireland in the 1950’s. For Jimmy, life was a carnival with friends to play with and comics to read. His father, Arthur (Colin Lane) carries a painful grudge from the past when he fought in the Irish civil war. When Jimmy steals money from his neighbour, Josie (Niall O’Brien) during a church service, the conflict of the past resurfaces, including the revelation that Josie and Arthur fought against each other for the love of Catherine (Marian Quinn), who is now Arthur’s wife. Civil instability is rekindled in the feud that occurs between neighbours. Also starring Darren McHugh.

results.title: Broadcast news (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: James L. Brooks, Gracie Films, James L. Brooks Films and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Three ambitious workaholics are set loose in a network TV newsroom where their professional and personal lives become hopelessly cross wired. Writer-director James L. Brooks is a filmmaker who is able to brilliantly combine comedy and drama with rich characters and unforgettable dialogue. His satire on the media can also be seen on ‘The Simpsons’ for which he is Executive Producer. He paints a savage, knowing, hilarious look at the television news industry and also what can happen to your personal life when your job consumes you. The performances are simply phenomenal. William Hurt gives depth to a dimbulb anchor, but Holly Hunter and Albert Brooks walk away with the movie. Cast includes Jack Nicholson (unbilled) and Joan Cusack. Music by Bill Conti.

results.title: Britannia Hospital
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Clive Parsons, Davina Belling and EMI/Parlophone
results.brief_description: Set in a hospital awaiting a royal visit to celebrate its 500th anniversary, this film combines black humour with social criticism to expose the misuse of National Health funds. Malcolm McDowell plays a reporter who sneaks into the hospital with a video camera to capture a mad doctor’s experiments, from funds meant for socialized medicine, to create Frankenstein creatures.

results.title: Britain now
results.creator_credit: John Spencer, Stuart Legg and Anglo-Scottish Pictures
results.brief_description: In 1945, Britain emerged from the war to find that, although victorious, there lay ahead a tremendous task of reconstruction; cities to be rebuilt, trade to be revived and exports to be stepped up. The film tells the story of Britain’s post-war recovery, thanks to the courage and determination of her people. Overseas, three great nations have achieved independence within the Commonwealth, and in the Dependencies, new constitutions are paving the way to self-government. Narrated by Leo Genn.

results.title: Brisbane 1982: the twelfth Commonwealth Games
results.creator_credit: Terence McMahon and Terence McMahon Productions
results.brief_description: Produced as part of Comalco’s sponsorship of the Commonwealth Games to be held in Brisbane in 1982. Includes historic newsreel footage of major performances by Australians in the past Commonwealth Games. Also shows some of Australia’s athletes training for the 1982 Games.

results.title: Broken blossoms [DVD]
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: A young Chinese man, disillusioned by life in London, shelters the daughter of a brutish prize fighter, whom he has adored at a distance. Her father, alerted by an informer, comes after them. This is a deceptively simple chamber piece (most of it takes place in two interior sets) in contrast to the epic scale of Intolerance and Birth of a Nation. Griffith’s ties with Victorian theatre and literature were blended with the visual resources of the cinema in a new lyrically intense romanticism, the perfect context for Gish’s unforgettable portrayal of quiet vulnerability complemented by Barthelmess’s gentle emotionalism. Tinted version with musical soundtrack. Cast: Lillian Gish, Richard Barthelmess, Donald Crisp.

results.title: Broadcast news
results.creator_credit: James L. Brooks, Gracie Films, James L. Brooks Films and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Three ambitious workaholics are set loose in a network TV newsroom where their professional and personal lives become hopelessly cross wired. Writer-director James L. Brooks is a filmmaker who is able to brilliantly combine comedy and drama with rich characters and unforgettable dialogue. His satire on the media can also be seen on ‘The Simpsons’ for which he is Executive Producer. He paints a savage, knowing, hilarious look at the television news industry and also what can happen to your personal life when your job consumes you. The performances are simply phenomenal. William Hurt gives depth to a dimbulb anchor, but Holly Hunter and Albert Brooks walk away with the movie. Cast includes Jack Nicholson (unbilled) and Joan Cusack. Music by Bill Conti.
